data.name: TAP11 Meine leichte Weisse
data.description: Enjoy wholeheartedly: "Meine leichte Weisse" – the wheat beer with less alcohol and the full aromatic wheat beer flavour. This light wheat beer goes perfectly for lunch or as a light drink in the afternoon. Its refreshingly tangy note offers delectable, delightful moments and it’s suitable for all occasions – of course, as the regular beer in the evening as well.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

style.name: German-Style Leichtes Weizen / Weissbier
style.description: The German word leicht means light, and as such these beers are light versions of Hefeweizen. Leicht Weissbier is top fermented and cloudy like Hefeweizen. The phenolic and estery aromas and flavors typical of Weissbiers are more subdued in Leichtes Weizen. Hop flavor and aroma are normally absent. The overall flavor profile is less complex than Hefeweizen due to decreased alcohol content. There is less yeasty flavor present. Leichtes Weissbier has diminished mouth feel relative to Hefeweizen, and is a low-bodied beer. No diacetyl should be perceived. The beer may have a broad range of color from pale golden to pale amber.

breweries.name: Schneider Weisse
breweries.description: The wheat beer specialists of the Schneider brewery are regularly awarded at international competitions. This proves that they are justly considered as world classics. A unique variety of distinguishing wheat beer specialties is being brewed at Bavaria’s oldest wheat beer brewery strictly following the Reinheitsgebot. The brewer, Georg Schneider VI, presents his family of wheat beer specialties:

data.name: The Gruesome Twosome
data.description:
The stars of our canning line are Dave and Matt, two dedicated dudes who lovingly coax our beer into the 12oz vessels you find around town. They're dedicated not only to our beer, but apparently each other, since they work the same hours all the time. It's so common to see those two busting it out in the back of the brewery that Bill, our Packaging Manager, has dubbed them "The Gruesome Twosome."

This Imperial Dunkelweizen was brewed in their honor. Next time you crack open a Holy City can, give a toast to teamwork!

breweries.name: Holy City Brewing
breweries.description: Holy City Brewing, established July 20, 2011, is a craft brewery located in North Charleston, SC. We strive to create hand crafted ales and lagers with our 15bbl system. We are proud to be a part of the Charleston community and look forward to providing you with great beer.

breweries.name: Ceveceria del Centro
breweries.description:
WE ARE THE CRAFT BEER OF COSTA RICA

We brew our beer adhering the German Beer Purity Law, “Reinheitsgoebot”, adopted on April 23rd, 1516 by William IV of Bavaria. According to this law, only four ingredients can be used in the production of beer: water, malted barley, yeast and hops.

data.name: Ur-Weisse
data.description:
“The union of wheaty freshness and dark malt often produces a fullness of taste and complexity”, explains the world-famous English beer commentator Michael Jackson. 
This also applies to the Ayinger Ur-Weisse, which is a strong amber-colored, yeast cloudy wheat beer. The beer is strong with the first taste and malty in aroma. The top-fermented, yeasty taste sensation is unmistakable. This beer is rich in sparkle and has just a touch of a special bitter quality. The fruity, malty mild aroma will have you won you over immediately!

breweries.name: Brauerei Ayinger
breweries.description:
The Ayinger Brewery (pronounced "eye-ing-gr"; German: Brauerei Aying) is a medium-sized German brewery located in Aying, Bavaria, about 25 km from Munich. Approximately 10% of Ayinger beers are exported, mainly to Italy, the United States, and the rest of Europe. Ayinger beers have been frequent award winners in international beer competitions.

For some years, a range of beer was brewed under the Ayingerbrau name by Samuel Smith's Brewery in Tadcaster, United Kingdom. Although the Ayinger logo was used, the recipes and range were different from those of the Ayinger Brewery. The arrangement ended in spring 2006, at which point Samuel Smith's rebranded the beers. Distribution of the Ayinger range of beer followed that summer. Because the Oktoberfest in Munich does not allow breweries outside its city limits to participate, Ayinger Brewery organizes many smaller festivals in the countryside around Munich.

data.name: Ur-Weizen
data.description: A delicious fruity, 100% organic wheat beer that manages to surprise. The taste experience begins slightly bitter, but changes unexpectedly soft sweet. With a short, subtle bitterness in the aftertaste. Touches of clove and wheat provide refinement. Because of its fresh taste this beer is a real thirst quencher. In his element on balmy summer days.
data.foodPairings: Lighter meals, mussels, shrimp and other shellfish, salads and sushi.

data.name: Ustecka Rychtarka Weizenbier
data.description:
Yeasty lager 11° with 4,4%  content of alcohol, top-fermented.
It contains: water, balanced 50% share of barley and frumentaceous malt, two kinds of quality hops from Žatec.
Characteristics: light yellow colour with rich foam, higher content of proteins, esters and carbon dioxide.
Flavour: pleasantly bitter with fine intensity of fruity aromas, mainly banana aroma and slight touch of clove.

breweries.name: Pivovar hotel Na Rychtě
breweries.description:
This storied hotel with a brewery dating from the 19th century is a 3-minute walk from the Usti nad Labem train station and 2.9 km from the Střekov Castle. 

The simple rooms with refined furniture, parquet floors and photographs of the historic venue also feature free Wi-Fi and flat-screen TVs. Kids ages 3 and younger are welcome without charge.

Freebies include parking, a breakfast buffet and beer. A rustic-chic restaurant/bar and brewery features arched ceilings and shaded outdoor seating. Brewery tours are available. Other amenities include bike storage and cleaning facilities. Pets are welcome.

breweries.name: Wet Dog Cafe & Astoria Brewing Company
breweries.description:
The Wet Dog Café was founded in 1995. The Brewery was added in 1997 under the name Pacific Rim Brewery. The name of the Brewery was changed to Astoria Brewing Co. in 2005 to commemorate Astoria’s First Brewing Company which was established in 1872. The Wet Dog was named after….the original owners dog…he loved the water and was always WET.

Our Brew Master uses only the finest ingredients to create our exceptional beers. Each beer is handcrafted using a wide range of hops & grains, thus creating unique flavors. It takes approximately 2 weeks for grain, water & hops to become our tasty brews. Our brewery has a 4 barrel system & in 2008 we added two 8 barrel fermenting tanks allowing us to produce over 800 barrels annually.

data.name: Water Tower Wheat
data.description: Amber in color, our “leichte weisse” is a subtle German style wheat beer made for sweltering double headers during the Dog Days of summer.

breweries.name: Bull Durham Beer Company
breweries.description: The Bull Durham Beer Company is located in the Durham Bulls Athletic Park in downtown Durham, NC. BDBCo is the first-of-its-kind in Minor League Baseball as the only craft brewery owned by a Minor League team.  We offer the freshest beer during the minor league season at the Bullpen Taproom, and year round at the shaded beer garden just outside the stadium. Our beers will also be served at restaurants and events on the American Tobacco Campus all year around.

data.name: Weissbier
data.description: This German wheat beer pours a golden straw with a crisp white head. It starts out with a soft bready note, followed by banana and apple tones, moving to a mid palate of clove, biscuits, and citrus tartness, with a crisp, clean, dry finish. Brewed with Weyermann Pilsner and Pale Wheat malt, Perle hops, and our proprietary German ale yeast strain.

breweries.name: Redwood Curtain Brewing
breweries.description:
We desire to share our passion and interest in craft beer with everyone from the first time sipper to the seasoned enthusiast. Providing academic and hands on experiences are a big part of this desire to help people expand and trust their own senses.

All of our handcrafted artisan ales are served and properly aged, to deliver maximum flavor and character. Our expressive beers can be very complex and assertive, but the with the ultimate goal of proper balance. We only use premium domestic and imported malts and hops, Humboldt County water and our multiply yeast strains. You will not find any artificial additives or preservatives in our beers.

We trust that our craft beer and brewing techniques convey our philosophies concerning family, friends, community, education and living life to its fullest. Cheers!

data.name: Weissbier
data.description: A celebration of traditional German wheat beers, our Weissbier features the classic banana and clove flavors, with the  refreshing tartness and citrus  notes that can only be found when the beer is at its freshest. We serve the beer cloudy on purpose, as the suspended yeast is crucial to its overall impression.

breweries.name: Ponysaurus Brewing
breweries.description:
Ponysaurus is a new brewery based in Durham, North Carolina, focused on perfecting balanced styles and finding ways to make beers you’ve always imagined.

Yes, our logo is a mix between a mean-looking Tyrannosaurus Rex and a stately-looking Equus Ferus Caballus. What’s better than a pony, and what’s better than a dinosaur? Both. 

We look at beer with a kind of childlike wonder. Beer is alchemy, the holiest magic. And even though we take what we do very seriously, we never want to forget how magical it is. The name constantly reminds us of that.

When you glance at our label, it looks classic and refined. Then you take a second look and you realize it's a horse with tiny T-Rex arms.

We wanted the name to have the same effect as the beer. To make you look—and taste—twice.

Also, it's pretty damn unforgettable.

Oh yeah. That guy up there grinnin' like a shot fox? That's Keil Jansen, our Brewmaster. He's alright.

breweries.name: Kokopelli Beer Company
breweries.description: Kokopelli Beer Company is a small brewpub located in the Solaire Shoppes at 8931 Harlan Street in Westminster Colorado, just across from the future Westminster Mall renovation. We enjoy brewing quality handcrafted ales and meeting new folks, so we decided to put them together. As a brew pub, we offer a small menu to compliment our ales with items such as pizzas, sandwiches, salads and more.

breweries.name: Rockford Brewing Company
breweries.description: RBC produces world class beers using traditional and innovative brewing techniques and ingredients. As a company, we strive to create unique beers with influences from countries around the world including the United States, Belgium, Germany, the United Kingdom, and the newest emerging craft beer location that has the world watching; Michigan. Part of our niche is working closely with West Michigan farmers and local ingredients on a seasonal basis. We love to incorporate West Michigan agricultural products into our offerings!

data.name: Whitewater Weizen
data.description: This unfiltered German-style wheat beer is brewed for summer enjoyment with a Bavarian yeast to give it the refreshing spicy overtones that make Weizens so unique. Whitewater Weizen is as exciting and exhilarating as a run through the rapids.

breweries.name: Central Waters Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Brewing since 1998, Central Waters Brewing Company is built on the solid reputation of producing the finest quality beer in Central Wisconsin: Ouisconsing Red Ale, Happy Heron Pale Ale, Mudpuppy Porter, and many more.

Currently, Central Waters Brewing Company services over 200 retail locations in Central Wisconsin, and has expanded its product line to include 18 beer styles. Moving from Junction City to a new facility in Amherst, Wisconsin in January of 2007, Central Waters can better support the growing demand. CWBC continues to build on the solid reputation of producing the finest quality beers in Central Wisconsin.
